wiki_catalogs.name: Project Overview
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the SERVER application. Explain its purpose as a Flask-based backend system for managing Site Acceptance Test (SAT) reports with multi-stage approval workflows. Describe the core architecture, including modular design using blueprints, separation of API and web routes, and integration with Celery and Redis. Highlight key features such as user management, report creation, document generation, and role-based access control. Illustrate the high-level data flow from user input through approval to final report delivery. Include deployment context (IIS, WSGI) and development lifecycle tools. Provide a conceptual overview suitable for new developers while linking to deeper technical sections for implementation details. Use diagrams to show system context and component interaction.

wiki_catalogs.name: Authentication API
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create API documentation for the authentication endpoints under /api/v1/auth. Document all HTTP methods including POST /login, POST /logout, POST /refresh-token, and GET /user-info. Specify request and response schemas using Marshmallow models from api.schemas.AuthRequest and api.schemas.UserSchema. Detail authentication mechanisms: session-based for web clients and JWT for API clients. Explain CSRF protection requirements and token refresh logic. Include examples of successful and failed login attempts, token expiration behavior, and MFA handling if applicable. Document error codes (401, 403, 422) and security headers. Provide Python and JavaScript examples for handling authentication flow, including storing tokens and handling refresh. Address integration with Flask-Login and token validation middleware in api/security.py.

wiki_catalogs.name: User Model
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for the User model in the SERVER application. Detail all fields including id, full_name, email, password_hash, role, status, created_date, and requested_role. Explain the UserMixin integration with Flask-Login and its implications for session management. Document the password hashing mechanism using Werkzeug's generate_password_hash and check_password_hash. Describe the role-based access control (Admin, Engineer, Automation Manager, PM) and status lifecycle (Pending, Active, Disabled). Include the relationship with ReportEdit for audit tracking and Notification for user-specific alerts. Explain the is_active property and its role in authentication. Provide examples of user creation, password setup, and status transitions. Address security considerations such as password storage and email uniqueness constraints. Include performance notes on indexing the email field and query patterns used in authentication workflows.

wiki_catalogs.name: Report Creation Workflow
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the report creation workflow. Thoroughly explain the step-by-step process engineers follow to create SAT reports using the SAT wizard interface. Document the form structure, field validations, and dynamic data population from templates. Explain how user input is processed through Flask-WTF forms and validated using Marshmallow schemas. Detail the integration with the `SATReport` model and the creation of draft records with proper ownership and status initialization. Include concrete examples from `routes/reports.py` showing route handlers and form processing logic. Address common issues such as incomplete form submission, validation errors, and session timeouts during creation. Provide guidance on handling large form payloads and optimizing frontend-backend data exchange.

wiki_catalogs.name: Authentication Mechanisms
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed documentation for the authentication subsystem of the SERVER application. Explain the implementation of session-based authentication using Flask-Login, including login, logout, and session persistence mechanisms. Document JWT-based token generation and validation for API endpoints, including token expiration and refresh strategies. Describe the integration of multi-factor authentication (MFA) if present, including TOTP or email-based verification flows. Detail the secure handling of credentials, password hashing with bcrypt or similar, and protection against brute-force attacks. Include configuration options from secrets.py and environment-specific settings. Provide code examples from authentication.py showing decorator usage, login flow, and user loader integration. Address common issues such as session fixation, expired tokens, and CSRF token mismatches during login. Discuss performance considerations for authentication under high load and caching strategies for user lookups.

wiki_catalogs.name: Configuration Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the configuration management system of the SERVER application. Explain the hierarchical YAML-based configuration structure using environment-specific files (development, testing, production) and the role of config/manager.py in loading and merging configurations. Detail how sensitive data is handled via config/secrets.py and its integration with the main configuration system. Document the purpose and structure of app.yaml as the base configuration and how overrides are applied per environment. Include practical examples of setting database URIs, feature flags, and API keys. Address best practices for managing configuration across environments, avoiding secrets leakage, and validating configuration integrity. Provide troubleshooting guidance for common issues such as missing environment variables, incorrect YAML syntax, and unexpected configuration overrides.

wiki_catalogs.name: Unit Testing
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the unit testing sub-system of the SERVER application. Thoroughly explain the implementation of isolated tests for core components such as authentication logic, data models, and utility functions. Document the use of pytest fixtures from conftest.py and factory_boy patterns in test factories for creating mock data. Include concrete examples from test_auth.py demonstrating login validation and role checking, and from test_models.py showing model persistence and relationship integrity. Explain test organization, assertion strategies, and database transaction rollback using SQLite in-memory during test execution. Address common issues such as test flakiness, dependency mocking, and maintaining test isolation. Provide best practices for writing fast, deterministic unit tests with high code coverage and integration into pre-commit hooks and CI pipelines.

wiki_catalogs.name: Email Notifications
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the email notification system powered by Celery and SMTP. Explain how email_tasks.py defines asynchronous tasks for sending notifications on key events such as report submission, approval, and rejection. Document the integration with Flask-Mail or SMTP via configuration in app.yaml and secrets.py. Include examples of email template rendering using Jinja2 from the templates directory. Describe error handling and retry mechanisms in case of delivery failure, leveraging Celery’s retry logic and failure_handler.py. Provide configuration steps for setting up outbound email, including TLS/SSL settings, authentication methods, and testing with mail traps. Address common issues like spam filtering, missing templates, and task queue bottlenecks, with troubleshooting guidance and performance optimization tips for high-volume scenarios.

wiki_catalogs.name: Logging Configuration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for the logging subsystem of the SERVER application. Explain the configuration of structured JSON logging with appropriate log levels (DEBUG, INFO, WARNING, ERROR, CRITICAL) and contextual metadata such as request ID, user ID, and timestamp. Detail how logs are formatted, routed, and written to both file and external systems. Document integration with Flask’s logging system and initialization within app.py. Include examples of log entries for key operations like user login, report submission, and API errors. Address log rotation, retention policies, and security considerations for sensitive data in logs. Provide guidance on reading and filtering logs for troubleshooting.

wiki_catalogs.name: Report Core
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed documentation for the core Report model which serves as the foundation for all report types in the system. Explain its role as a polymorphic base entity using UUID-based id as primary key and type field to distinguish between SAT, FDS, HDS, and other report types. Document all fields including status (DRAFT, PENDING, APPROVED), document metadata (title, reference, revision), user tracking (user_email, prepared_by), versioning (version, edit_count), timestamps (created_at, updated_at), and approval workflow tracking (approvals_json, approval_notification_sent, submitted_at, approved_at, approved_by). Detail the one-to-one relationships with specialized report models via foreign keys. Explain the locked flag for finalization control and the use of JSON fields for flexible data storage. Provide examples of creating a new Report instance, transitioning through approval states, and querying by status or type. Address performance considerations such as indexing on status and type fields for efficient filtering, and best practices for updating related entities. Include guidance on how the Report model integrates with audit logging via ReportEdit and version history via ReportVersion.

wiki_catalogs.name: Document Versioning System
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for the ReportVersion model, which enables full document version control within the SAT Report Generator system. Detail each field including version_number (R0, R1, etc.), created_at timestamp, created_by user identifier, change_summary for audit context, data_snapshot storing the complete JSON state of the report at that version, file_path pointing to generated documents, and is_current flag indicating the active version. Explain how the system automatically creates version snapshots during key transitions such as submission, approval, and manual edits. Describe the relationship between ReportVersion and the parent Report entity, and how version restoration works through the API. Provide examples of version comparison logic, data_snapshot deserialization, and file path management. Address performance considerations for storing large JSON snapshots, indexing strategies for time-based queries, and storage implications of long-term version retention. Document the integration with background tasks for asynchronous version processing and the API endpoints that expose version history to users.

wiki_catalogs.name: Technology Stack & Dependencies
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the technology stack of the SERVER application. Detail the primary frameworks: Flask for web handling, Flask-RESTX for API development, Flask-SQLAlchemy for ORM, and Celery with Redis for background tasks. Explain the role of supporting libraries including Marshmallow for serialization, docxtpl for DOCX generation, and cryptography for security. Document configuration management via YAML files and secret handling. Describe the testing stack (pytest, Locust) and quality assurance tools. Provide version compatibility notes and dependency resolution guidance. Include practical examples of how these technologies integrate within the application, such as Celery task invocation from Flask routes. Address common setup issues and virtual environment configuration.

wiki_catalogs.name: User Management API
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create API documentation for the user management endpoints under /api/v1/users. Document GET /users, POST /users, GET /users/{id}, PUT /users/{id}, and DELETE /users/{id} operations. Define request/response schemas using UserCreateSchema, UserUpdateSchema, and UserResponseSchema from api.schemas. Explain role-based access control (Admin, Engineer, AM, PM) and permission requirements for each operation. Detail user registration workflow, approval status, and password reset functionality. Include examples of creating users with different roles, updating profile information, and retrieving user lists with filtering. Document error conditions like duplicate emails, invalid roles, and forbidden operations. Explain integration with background tasks for email notifications and audit logging via security/audit.py.

wiki_catalogs.name: Report Models
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed documentation for the core Report models: Report, SATReport, and related report types (FDSReport, HDSReport, SiteSurveyReport, SDSReport, FATReport). Explain the polymorphic design pattern using UUID-based report_id as foreign key. Document the Report entity's fields including id, type, status, document metadata, versioning (version, edit_count), timestamps, and approval tracking (approvals_json, approval_notification_sent, submitted_at, approved_at, approved_by). Detail the one-to-one relationships between Report and its specialized counterparts. For SATReport, document the data_json field storing full form payload and summary fields (date, purpose, scope) for querying. Describe image URL storage patterns using JSON arrays (scada_image_urls, trends_image_urls, alarm_image_urls). Cover other report types' specialized fields and their use cases. Explain the ReportTemplate model for managing DOCX templates with versioning, usage tracking, and field definitions. Include the ScheduledReport model for automated generation. Provide examples of report creation, type specialization, and template usage. Address performance considerations including indexing on status and type fields, and JSON field querying strategies.

wiki_catalogs.name: Approval Workflow
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the multi-stage approval process. Explain the state transitions from 'submitted' → 'under_review' → 'approved/rejected' with role-based access control enforced by decorators like `@role_required`. Detail how Automation Managers and Project Managers interact with pending reports through dedicated dashboard views. Document the comment system, rejection with feedback, and re-submission flow. Explain the audit trail implementation that logs all approval actions using the `audit.py` module. Include examples from `routes/approval.py` showing status update handlers and permission checks. Address edge cases like concurrent approvals, expired sessions during review, and handling of orphaned pending reports. Provide performance considerations for querying large approval queues.

wiki_catalogs.name: Role-Based Access Control
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop comprehensive documentation for the role-based access control (RBAC) system in the SERVER application. Detail the roles defined in the system (Admin, Engineer, Automation Manager, PM) and their associated permissions. Explain the implementation of decorators such as @role_required_api and @login_required used across routes and API endpoints. Document how user roles are stored in the database (User model), checked during request processing, and enforced at both web and API layers. Include examples from route handlers and API methods showing permission enforcement patterns. Describe the integration between Flask-Login's current_user and role evaluation logic. Address edge cases such as role elevation, permission inheritance, and handling of unauthenticated or unauthorized access attempts. Provide guidance on extending the RBAC system with new roles or granular permissions. Include troubleshooting tips for common authorization failures and debugging techniques using logging or test suites.

wiki_catalogs.name: Production Deployment
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the production deployment process of the SERVER application. Cover the complete workflow from environment preparation to service activation. Explain the role of IIS as the web server and how iis_web_config.xml defines site bindings, handlers, and security settings. Document the use of wsgi.py as the WSGI entry point and its integration with IIS via wfastcgi. Detail the purpose of run_production.bat and production_start.py in launching the application with optimal settings. Include step-by-step instructions for setting up the Python environment, installing dependencies, configuring application pools, and enabling HTTPS using run_https_443.py. Address process management, logging setup, and startup behavior under Windows. Provide troubleshooting guidance for common deployment failures such as module import errors, permission issues, port conflicts, and WSGI handshake failures.

wiki_catalogs.name: Integration Testing
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the integration testing layer of the SERVER application. Explain how tests validate interactions between components such as API endpoints, database operations, file handling, and email delivery. Use examples from test_api_endpoints.py to demonstrate authenticated requests, status code validation, and payload verification across /api/v1 routes. Detail test_database_operations.py's approach to testing complex queries, transaction rollbacks, and ORM relationships. Describe how test_email_notifications.py verifies Celery task integration with SMTP simulation. Include setup patterns using pytest fixtures for test clients, temporary databases, and mocked external services. Address common challenges like environment parity, test data seeding, and race conditions. Provide guidance on debugging failed integrations and optimizing test execution speed through parallelization and resource cleanup.

wiki_catalogs.name: Webhooks
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the webhook system that enables event-driven integration with external services. Explain how routes/webhooks.py exposes configurable endpoints to notify third-party systems when critical events occur (e.g., report submitted, approved, rejected). Document the payload structure, HTTP methods, and authentication mechanisms (e.g., API keys, HMAC signatures) used to secure webhook deliveries. Describe how webhook targets are registered and managed, including retry logic for failed deliveries and logging via monitoring/logging_config.py. Provide code examples showing how events are triggered from business logic in models.py and routed through the API layer. Include security considerations such as validating callback URLs, preventing SSRF attacks, and protecting sensitive data in payloads. Offer troubleshooting guidance for common issues like timeout errors, misconfigured endpoints, and replay attacks.

wiki_catalogs.name: Metrics Collection
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the metrics collection system in the SERVER application. Describe how application-level metrics such as HTTP request rates, response times, background task duration, and system resource usage are collected and exposed. Explain the implementation using monitoring/metrics.py to define counters, gauges, and timers. Document how periodic monitoring tasks in tasks/monitoring_tasks.py gather and report performance data. Include integration points with external monitoring tools like Prometheus or Datadog. Provide examples of metric instrumentation in routes and API endpoints. Address best practices for labeling, scoping, and avoiding metric cardinality issues. Cover use cases for capacity planning and performance regression detection.

wiki_catalogs.name: SAT Report
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop comprehensive documentation for the SATReport model that extends the core Report entity with Site Acceptance Test-specific data. Explain the one-to-one relationship with the parent Report through report_id foreign key and the use of data_json to store the complete form payload as serialized JSON. Document the purpose of summary fields (date, purpose, scope) for efficient querying without parsing full JSON. Detail the image URL storage mechanism using JSON arrays for scada_image_urls, trends_image_urls, and alarm_image_urls, including encoding/decoding patterns and frontend integration. Provide examples of extracting key information from data_json, updating image references after upload, and generating reports using template engines. Explain how SATReport integrates with document generation workflows and approval processes. Address performance considerations including partial JSON querying strategies, indexing recommendations, and caching approaches for frequently accessed reports. Include troubleshooting guidance for common issues like malformed JSON, missing images, and data consistency between parent Report and SATReport.

wiki_catalogs.name: Edit Audit Trail
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the ReportEdit model that serves as the comprehensive audit trail for all changes made to reports. Explain the purpose and implementation of each field: before_json and after_json capturing the full state transition, changes_summary providing human-readable context, editor_user_id and editor_email for accountability, created_at timestamping, and version_before/version_after tracking revision progression. Describe how the system automatically logs edits through model hooks in the application lifecycle, ensuring no changes go unrecorded. Detail the relationship between ReportEdit and both Report and User models, enabling powerful query capabilities. Provide code examples showing audit log generation during report updates, diff computation between JSON states, and presentation of change summaries in the UI. Address security considerations for protecting audit data integrity, performance implications of high-frequency editing, and database indexing strategies for efficient audit log retrieval. Document how administrators can use this data for compliance reporting and troubleshooting.

wiki_catalogs.name: API Endpoints Reference
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create API documentation for the Flask-RESTX based RESTful API endpoints under /api/v1. For each endpoint group (auth, users, reports, files, admin, config), document HTTP methods, URL patterns, request/response schemas using Marshmallow schemas from api/schemas.py, authentication requirements (JWT or session), and error codes. Include detailed examples of request payloads and responses for common operations like user login, report submission, and file upload. Explain API versioning strategy and rate limiting implementation. Document security considerations including CSRF protection for web clients and token expiration. Provide client integration examples in Python and JavaScript. Address pagination, filtering, and sorting mechanisms in list endpoints.

wiki_catalogs.name: Report Management API
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create API documentation for the report management endpoints under /api/v1/reports. Document full CRUD operations: GET /reports (with pagination, filtering by status/owner), POST /reports (creation), GET /reports/{id}, PUT /reports/{id} (editing), DELETE /reports/{id}. Include specialized endpoints like POST /reports/{id}/submit, POST /reports/{id}/approve, POST /reports/{id}/reject. Define schemas using ReportCreateSchema, ReportUpdateSchema, and ReportResponseSchema from api.schemas. Explain state transitions in the approval workflow and validation rules enforced during submission. Detail document generation triggers via Celery tasks in tasks/report_tasks.py. Provide examples of report creation with SAT-specific data, status updates, and retrieving version history. Document rate limiting for frequent edits and integration with audit logging.

wiki_catalogs.name: Audit Models
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for the audit and versioning models: ReportVersion, ReportEdit, Notification, ReportComment, and UserAnalytics. Detail ReportVersion's role in document version control with fields like version_number, created_at, created_by, change_summary, data_snapshot, file_path, and is_current. Explain how data_snapshot preserves JSON state for historical tracking. Document ReportEdit as the audit trail for changes, capturing before_json, after_json, changes_summary, editor details, and version transitions. Describe Notification's structure for in-app alerts with type discrimination, read state, and action URLs. Cover ReportComment's hierarchical comment system with parent_comment_id for threading and mentions_json for user collaboration. Explain UserAnalytics for performance tracking with KPIs like reports_created, reports_approved, avg_completion_time, and approval_cycle_time. Include the Webhook model for event-driven integrations and SavedSearch for user productivity. Provide examples of audit log generation, notification creation, and analytics aggregation. Address data retention policies, indexing strategies for time-series queries, and performance implications of high-volume audit logging.

wiki_catalogs.name: Document Generation Pipeline
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the document generation pipeline. Explain how approved reports trigger asynchronous DOCX generation via Celery tasks in `report_tasks.py`. Detail the use of `docxtpl` for populating Jinja2 templates with dynamic data from the `SATReport` model. Document the file storage workflow, including temporary file handling and permanent attachment via the `files.py` API. Explain error handling during template rendering, such as missing context variables or malformed DOCX templates. Include examples showing the task invocation pattern from `api/reports.py` and the `generate_report_document` task implementation. Address customization options for templates, performance implications of large document generation, and strategies for handling binary file downloads securely.

wiki_catalogs.name: CSRF Protection and Session Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed documentation for CSRF protection and session security mechanisms in the SERVER application. Explain how Flask-WTF's CSRF protection is implemented across forms and AJAX requests, including token generation, validation, and synchronization with frontend JavaScript (csrf_manager.js). Document the configuration and usage of secure session management with Redis-backed storage via cache/session_store.py. Cover session cookie settings such as HttpOnly, Secure, and SameSite flags enforced in middleware.py. Describe the workflow for CSRF token injection into templates and handling in single-page interactions. Include examples from form submissions and API calls requiring CSRF tokens. Address known vulnerabilities such as CSRF bypass in API endpoints, session hijacking risks, and mitigation through token invalidation. Discuss performance implications of server-side session storage and strategies for scaling Redis usage. Provide troubleshooting steps for CSRF errors and session expiration issues.

wiki_catalogs.name: SSL & Security Hardening
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content focused on SSL/TLS implementation and security hardening for the SERVER application in production. Explain how run_https_443.py enables HTTPS on port 443 using Python's ssl module and certificate configuration. Document the differences between run_local_https.py (development) and production SSL setup. Detail integration with security/headers.py to enforce secure HTTP headers (HSTS, CSP, X-Content-Type-Options). Cover middleware-level protections such as CSRF enforcement and secure session handling. Explain configuration of secure cookies, strict transport security, and TLS version requirements in production.yaml. Include steps for obtaining and installing SSL certificates, validating SSL configuration, and testing secure connections. Provide troubleshooting guidance for certificate errors, mixed content warnings, and insecure header issues.

wiki_catalogs.name: End-to-End Testing
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the end-to-end (E2E) testing framework in the SERVER application. Focus on simulating real user journeys across the web interface, including report creation, submission, approval workflows, and dashboard navigation. Use examples from test_user_workflows.py to illustrate full-cycle testing of login, form submission, and status tracking. Explain how test_approval_workflows.py validates multi-role interactions between Engineers, Automation Managers, and PMs. Detail test_report_workflows.py's coverage of SAT report lifecycle from draft to final approval. Document the use of headless browsers or client simulation, session management, and UI state validation. Address challenges such as test brittleness, timing dependencies, and asynchronous background tasks (e.g., email delivery). Provide best practices for maintaining reliable E2E tests, including page object patterns, explicit waits, and screenshot logging for debugging.

wiki_catalogs.name: CDN Integration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the CDN integration that optimizes delivery of static assets. Explain how flask_cdn.py integrates with a content delivery network to serve CSS, JavaScript, and image files from edge locations. Document configuration options in cdn.yaml including CDN provider settings, domain mapping, and asset versioning strategies. Describe cache invalidation workflows using Redis as a coordination layer via redis_client.py. Provide implementation examples showing how template helpers generate CDN-aware URLs for assets in static/. Address performance benefits, cost implications, and fallback mechanisms during CDN outages. Include best practices for cache headers, asset minification, and handling of dynamic vs. static content. Troubleshoot common issues such as broken asset links, stale content, and misconfigured SSL certificates on CDN endpoints.

wiki_catalogs.name: Distributed Tracing
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the distributed tracing implementation in the SERVER application. Explain how tracing.py enables end-to-end visibility across request flows, including web requests, API calls, and background task execution. Detail the use of trace IDs and span IDs to correlate operations across components. Document context propagation through request headers and integration with OpenTelemetry or similar standards. Illustrate how traces are generated during user interactions such as report creation or approval workflows. Include configuration for trace sampling, export formats, and backend integrations (e.g., Jaeger, Zipkin). Provide guidance on analyzing traces to diagnose latency bottlenecks and failed transactions.

wiki_catalogs.name: Other Report Types
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Document all non-SAT report types in the system: FDSReport, HDSReport, SiteSurveyReport, SDSReport, and FATReport. For each type, explain its business purpose and relationship to the core Report model via UUID-based report_id foreign key. Detail FDSReport's functional requirements, process description, and control philosophy fields. Describe HDSReport's system description, hardware_components (JSON array), and network_architecture fields. Cover SiteSurveyReport's comprehensive SCADA migration data including site details, hardware specifications (PLC, HMI, router), network configuration, mobile signal strength, and pre-departure checklist - all stored as structured JSON. Explain SDSReport's minimal structure focused on data_json storage. Detail FATReport's test_location, test_equipment (JSON array), and acceptance_criteria fields. Provide usage examples for each report type, showing how they are created, populated, and queried. Address common patterns across these models including consistent use of data_json for form payloads and foreign key relationships. Include guidance on extending the system with new report types and maintaining schema consistency.

wiki_catalogs.name: Notification System
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for the Notification model that powers both in-app alerts and email notifications. Detail each field including user_email recipient identifier, title and message content, type classification (approval_request, status_update, completion, etc.), related_submission_id linking to reports, read state tracking, created_at timestamp, and action_url for deep linking. Explain the to_dict() method that standardizes output format and the static methods for creating, retrieving, and counting notifications. Describe how the system generates notifications at key workflow moments such as report submission, approval decisions, and completion events. Provide examples of notification creation patterns, batch processing in background tasks, and real-time updates via polling mechanisms. Address performance considerations for high-volume notification scenarios, database indexing on user_email and read status, and the soft-delete pattern enabled by read state rather than record deletion. Document the integration with email delivery systems and the user interface components that display notification badges and lists.

wiki_catalogs.name: Data Models & ORM Mapping
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for the SQLAlchemy ORM models used in the SERVER application. Detail the core entities: User, Report, SATReport, Notification, ReportVersion, and ReportEdit. Document field definitions, data types, constraints, indexes, and relationships (one-to-many, many-to-one). Explain the inheritance structure and polymorphic models if present. Include database schema diagrams showing table relationships and foreign key constraints. Describe how Marshmallow schemas in api/schemas.py map to these models for serialization. Document data validation rules, lifecycle hooks, and business logic embedded in model methods. Address performance considerations like eager vs lazy loading and indexing strategies for query optimization.

wiki_catalogs.name: File Operations API
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create API documentation for the file operations endpoints under /api/v1/files. Document POST /files/upload, GET /files/download/{id}, GET /files/list, and DELETE /files/{id}. Specify multipart form-data requirements for uploads and response content types for downloads. Define FileUploadSchema and FileResponseSchema from api.schemas. Explain file storage backend (local or CDN), naming conventions, and security measures like MIME type validation and virus scanning if applicable. Detail integration with report submissions and email attachments via tasks/email_tasks.py. Include examples of uploading supporting documents for SAT reports and generating download URLs. Document size limits, allowed file types, and cleanup policies for temporary files.

wiki_catalogs.name: Collaboration & Edit Tracking
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for collaboration features including comments, edit tracking, and version history. Explain how users can add comments during review cycles using the collaboration endpoints. Detail the implementation of edit tracking that captures changes to report fields before submission. Document the versioning system that creates snapshots using the `ReportVersion` model upon major state transitions. Explain the UI integration with `pending_approval.html` and `edit.py` routes that highlight changes. Include examples from `api/versioning.py` showing version comparison APIs. Address data consistency challenges during concurrent edits, comment moderation workflows, and retention policies for edit history. Provide performance tips for querying version diffs on large reports.

wiki_catalogs.name: Input Validation and Security Headers
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed documentation for input validation and HTTP security headers enforcement in the SERVER application. Explain the implementation of input sanitization and validation routines in security/validation.py, including checks for SQL injection, XSS payloads, and malformed data. Document the use of Marshmallow schemas in api/schemas.py for request payload validation and error handling. Describe how security headers such as Content-Security-Policy, X-Content-Type-Options, X-Frame-Options, and Strict-Transport-Security are set via security/headers.py and injected into responses through middleware.py or Flask before_request handlers. Include configuration options for header values per environment (development, production). Provide real code examples showing header application and validation middleware in action. Address common misconfigurations, browser compatibility issues, and testing strategies for header enforcement. Discuss integration with frontend assets and CDN considerations. Offer troubleshooting guidance for blocked resources due to CSP and validation errors in API payloads.

wiki_catalogs.name: Performance Testing
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the performance testing strategy of the SERVER application. Explain the use of Locust (locustfile.py) for load testing API endpoints under concurrent user scenarios, measuring response times, error rates, and system bottlenecks. Detail test_api_performance.py and test_database_performance.py for targeted benchmarking of critical operations like report retrieval and bulk submissions. Include configuration of performance thresholds, test duration, and user ramp-up patterns. Document integration with run_performance_tests.py for automated execution and result aggregation. Highlight performance metrics captured, such as queries per second, cache hit ratios, and connection pool utilization. Address common issues like memory leaks, slow database queries, and thread contention. Provide optimization tips based on findings, including query indexing, caching strategies, and connection pooling adjustments. Recommend practices for regular performance regression testing in staging environments.

wiki_catalogs.name: API Key Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the API key management system that controls third-party access to the SERVER application's RESTful interfaces. Explain how api/keys.py implements CRUD operations for generating, listing, and revoking API keys with configurable permissions and expiration policies. Document the underlying data model in models.py, including key hashing (using cryptographic libraries), scopes, and associated user roles. Describe integration with the authentication pipeline in security/authentication.py and request validation in api/security.py. Provide usage examples showing how external clients include API keys in requests (header or query param) and how rate limiting is enforced per key. Cover security best practices such as avoiding key leakage in logs, enabling MFA for key creation, and auditing key usage. Include troubleshooting steps for unauthorized access errors, expired keys, and incorrect scope assignments.

wiki_catalogs.name: Database Query Monitoring
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for the database query monitoring system. Detail how query_analyzer.py captures, analyzes, and logs SQL queries executed by SQLAlchemy. Explain metrics collection on query execution time, frequency, and potential anti-patterns (e.g., N+1 queries, full table scans). Document integration with the application’s metrics system to expose slow query rates and connection pool utilization. Include examples of how query analysis is used to optimize performance in database-intensive operations like report generation and search. Address how developers can enable query logging in development and interpret output for optimization. Cover thresholds, alerting conditions, and correlation with application-level KPIs.

wiki_catalogs.name: Report Templates
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed documentation for the ReportTemplate model used to manage DOCX templates for automated report generation. Explain its fields including name, type (SAT, FDS, HDS, FAT, etc.), version, description, template_file (path to .docx), fields_json (JSON array defining required data fields), created_by, usage_count, and is_active status. Describe how templates are selected during report creation via the report_selector.html interface and validated against required fields. Document the versioning system and activation/deactivation workflow for template management. Provide examples of creating a new template, defining field mappings, and associating templates with specific report types. Explain how the document generation process (in report_tasks.py) uses these templates with docxtpl for dynamic content insertion. Address security considerations for template file storage and access control. Include troubleshooting guidance for template rendering failures, missing fields, and version conflicts. Discuss performance implications of template compilation and caching strategies for frequently used templates.

wiki_catalogs.name: Collaboration Features
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the ReportComment model that enables team collaboration on reports. Explain the hierarchical comment system with parent_comment_id enabling threaded discussions, user_email and user_name for attribution, comment_text content, field_reference for contextual anchoring to specific report sections, and resolution workflow with is_resolved, resolved_by, and resolved_at fields. Describe the mentions_json field that supports @-mentions of team members with JSON storage of referenced users. Detail the self-referential relationship that allows nested replies and the backref configuration for thread traversal. Provide examples of comment threading logic, mention parsing and notification triggering, and resolution status management. Address performance considerations for deeply nested comment threads, database indexing strategies for report_id and created_at queries, and UI patterns for rendering comment trees. Document how this system integrates with the notification framework to alert mentioned users and keep stakeholders informed of discussions.

wiki_catalogs.name: Business Logic Layer
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the business logic of the SAT report workflow. Explain the end-to-end process from report creation by engineers through multi-stage approval (Automation Manager → PM) to final document generation. Detail the state machine governing report status transitions and the validation rules applied at each stage. Describe the document generation pipeline using docxtpl templates and dynamic data population. Explain the collaboration features like comments and edit tracking. Document the integration between synchronous web requests and asynchronous Celery tasks for non-blocking operations. Include error handling strategies and rollback procedures for failed operations. Provide sequence diagrams showing control flow across components.

wiki_catalogs.name: Administrative API
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create API documentation for the administrative endpoints under /api/v1/admin. Document system-level operations including GET /admin/users (with filters), PUT /admin/users/{id}/role, POST /admin/system-backup, GET /admin/audit-log, and POST /admin/clear-cache. Define AdminUserUpdateSchema and SystemBackupSchema from api.schemas. Explain super-admin privileges required for these endpoints and comprehensive audit logging via security/audit.py. Detail database backup process integration with database/backup.py and cache invalidation using Redis. Include examples of bulk user management, triggering system backups, and retrieving audit trails. Document security considerations like IP restrictions, additional MFA requirements, and rate limiting for sensitive operations.

wiki_catalogs.name: Security Audit and Logging
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive documentation for the security audit and logging framework in the SERVER application. Detail the implementation of audit trails in security/audit.py, including logging of critical actions such as login attempts, report approvals, user management changes, and configuration updates. Explain how audit events are stored in the database (AuditLog model or similar), linked to user identities, and protected from tampering. Document integration with the application’s logging system (monitoring/logging_config.py) for log formatting, rotation, and external aggregation. Describe access controls for viewing audit logs via admin interfaces (routes/audit.py, api/admin.py). Include examples of audit log entries and their structure. Address compliance requirements such as GDPR or ISO27001 if applicable. Discuss performance considerations for high-volume logging and strategies for log retention and archival. Provide troubleshooting steps for missing audit entries and debugging logging pipeline issues.

wiki_catalogs.name: Scheduled Reports
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Document the ScheduledReport model that enables automated, recurring report generation. Explain its purpose in supporting periodic reporting requirements without manual intervention. Detail all fields: name, template_id (foreign key to ReportTemplate), schedule_type (daily, weekly, monthly), schedule_config (JSON cron-like configuration), user_email (creator), recipient_emails (JSON array of delivery targets), is_active flag, last_run, next_run, and created_at. Describe how the scheduling system integrates with Celery beat for task orchestration and how report_tasks.py handles execution. Provide examples of creating daily executive summaries or weekly compliance reports with multiple recipients. Explain the workflow from schedule evaluation to document generation and email delivery. Address error handling for failed executions and notification of delivery status. Include configuration guidance for setting up reliable scheduling infrastructure and monitoring scheduled task health. Discuss limitations and best practices for managing large volumes of scheduled reports.

wiki_catalogs.name: Analytics Framework
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for the UserAnalytics model that tracks performance metrics and KPIs across the organization. Detail each field including user_email for identification, date for time-series analysis, reports_created, reports_approved, and reports_rejected for productivity measurement, avg_completion_time and approval_cycle_time for process efficiency, on_time_percentage for timeliness, and custom_metrics JSON field for extensibility. Explain how the system aggregates data daily from completed workflows and updates these metrics automatically. Provide examples of analytics aggregation queries, time-series reporting, and dashboard visualizations that consume this data. Address performance considerations for high-cardinality queries, database indexing on user_email and date fields, and data retention policies for historical analysis. Document how administrators use this information for performance reviews, process optimization, and capacity planning, and how team leads access summary analytics through API endpoints.

wiki_catalogs.name: Security Architecture
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the security subsystem of the SERVER application. Describe the authentication mechanisms including session-based login, JWT tokens, and potential MFA support. Explain the implementation of CSRF protection using Flask-WTF and secure session management with Redis-backed storage. Detail the role-based access control system with decorators like @role_required_api and permission checks across routes and API endpoints. Document input validation strategies using security/validation.py and secure header enforcement via security/headers.py. Address security monitoring and audit logging integration. Include threat models for common web vulnerabilities (XSS, SQL injection, IDOR) and mitigation strategies implemented in the codebase.

wiki_catalogs.name: Configuration API
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create API documentation for the configuration endpoints under /api/v1/config. Document GET /config/settings, PUT /config/settings, and GET /config/schema. Explain the hierarchical configuration system with environment-specific overrides (development, testing, production). Define ConfigUpdateSchema and ConfigResponseSchema from api.schemas. Detail validation rules enforced by config/manager.py and secure handling of sensitive settings. Include examples of retrieving current configuration, updating system parameters like email settings or approval thresholds, and schema introspection for UI integration. Document access controls (admin-only), change auditing, and application restart requirements for certain changes. Address integration with dynamic configuration updates and validation against config/app.yaml structure.

wiki_catalogs.name: Deployment & Configuration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on deploying the SERVER application in production environments. Document the configuration hierarchy using YAML files (development, testing, production) and secret management via config/secrets.py. Explain the IIS setup process using iis_web_config.xml and the provided batch scripts for starting the application. Detail WSGI configuration with wsgi.py and process management considerations. Cover SSL/TLS setup using run_https_443.py and security hardening steps. Provide environment-specific configuration examples and database connection setup. Include troubleshooting guidance for common deployment issues like permission errors, missing dependencies, and port conflicts.

wiki_catalogs.name: Testing Strategy
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the testing architecture of the SERVER application. Describe the four-tier testing strategy: unit tests (test_auth.py, test_models.py), integration tests (test_api_endpoints.py, test_database_operations.py), end-to-end tests (test_user_workflows.py), and performance tests (locustfile.py). Explain the test pyramid distribution and coverage goals. Document the use of pytest fixtures in conftest.py, test factories, and database transaction rollback patterns. Detail performance testing methodology using Locust for API and database load testing. Provide guidance on running tests locally and in CI/CD environments. Include code coverage analysis using quality tools in scripts/ and best practices for writing effective tests.

wiki_catalogs.name: Developer Setup Guide
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on setting up a local development environment for the SERVER application. Provide step-by-step instructions for installing Python dependencies, configuring the development database, and initializing the application state using init_new_db.py. Explain how to run the server locally using run_local_https.py or debug_start.bat with hot reloading. Detail IDE setup recommendations and debugging configurations. Cover database migration management using manage_db.py and simple_migration.py. Include guidance on environment variable setup and switching between configuration profiles. Provide troubleshooting tips for common setup issues like port conflicts, missing modules, and database connection errors.

wiki_catalogs.name: External Integrations
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the external integration points of the SERVER application. Document the email notification system powered by Celery tasks in email_tasks.py, including SMTP configuration and template rendering. Explain the webhook system in routes/webhooks.py that allows external systems to receive event notifications (report submitted, approved, rejected). Describe the CDN integration through cache/flask_cdn.py for serving static assets with cache invalidation strategies. Cover API key management in api/keys.py for third-party access control. Provide implementation examples for each integration type and security considerations for exposing these endpoints to external systems.

wiki_catalogs.name: Monitoring & Observability
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the monitoring subsystem of the SERVER application. Describe the logging configuration using structured JSON logs with appropriate log levels and contextual data. Explain the metrics collection system for tracking key performance indicators like request latency, task processing time, and database query performance. Detail distributed tracing implementation for tracking requests across components. Document the integration with external monitoring tools and log aggregation systems. Cover database query analysis using database/query_analyzer.py and performance monitoring tasks in tasks/monitoring_tasks.py. Include alerting strategies and dashboard creation for operational visibility.

wiki_overview.content:
<blog>
# Comprehensive Project Analysis: SAT Report Generator

## 1. Project Introduction

The SAT Report Generator is a web-based application designed to streamline the creation, approval, and management of Site Acceptance Test (SAT) reports and related documentation. The system provides a comprehensive workflow for engineers to generate standardized reports, submit them for multi-stage approval, and distribute final documents to clients.

**Core Goals and Objectives:**
- Automate the SAT report generation process with template-based document creation
- Implement a multi-stage approval workflow with role-based access control
- Provide secure user authentication with session management and CSRF protection
- Enable document tracking, versioning, and audit trails
- Support integration with email notifications and external systems

**Target Audience:**
- Engineers who create SAT reports
- Automation Managers and Project Managers who approve reports
- System Administrators who manage users and system settings
- Clients who receive final approved reports

## 2. Technical Architecture

### Component Breakdown

The application follows a modular Flask-based architecture with clear separation of concerns. The system is organized into several key components:

```mermaid
flowchart TD
    A[Client] --> B[API Layer]
    B --> C[Business Logic]
    C --> D[Data Access]
    D --> E[(Database)]
    F[Static Assets] --> B
    G[Background Tasks] --> C
    H[Cache System] --> C
    I[Email Service] --> C
```

### Design Patterns

The application implements several architectural patterns:

- **Blueprint Pattern**: Flask blueprints are used to organize routes by functionality (auth, dashboard, reports, approval, etc.)
- **Repository Pattern**: The models.py file serves as a data access layer with SQLAlchemy ORM
- **Dependency Injection**: Configuration and services are initialized in app.py and injected into the application
- **Lazy Loading**: Blueprints and modules are imported only when needed to improve startup performance
- **Role-Based Access Control**: Decorators like @admin_required and @role_required enforce authorization

### System Relationships

```mermaid
graph LR
    A[Frontend] --> B[Flask App]
    B --> C[Database]
    B --> D[Redis Cache]
    B --> E[Email Service]
    B --> F[File Storage]
    G[Background Tasks] --> B
    H[Monitoring] --> B
    I[API Layer] --> B
    B --> J[Document Generation]
```

### Data Flow

```mermaid
flowchart TD
    A[User Input] --> B[Form Validation]
    B --> C[Business Logic Processing]
    C --> D[Database Operations]
    D --> E[Document Generation]
    E --> F[Approval Workflow]
    F --> G[Email Notifications]
    G --> H[Final Document Distribution]
    H --> I[Client]
```

## 3. Key Implementation

### Main Entry Points
- [app.py](app.py): Primary application entry point that creates and configures the Flask application
- [wsgi.py](wsgi.py): WSGI interface for production deployment
- [run_https_443.py](run_https_443.py): HTTPS server configuration

### Core Modules
- [models.py](models.py): Database models and ORM definitions
- [routes](routes/): Flask blueprints for handling HTTP requests
- [api](api/): RESTful API endpoints for authentication and database operations
- [tasks](tasks/): Background task processing with Celery

### Configuration Approach
- [config.py](config.py): Application configuration with environment-specific settings
- [config/](config/): YAML configuration files for different environments
- Environment variables: Sensitive data and configuration options

### External Dependencies
- [requirements.txt](requirements.txt): Core Python dependencies
- [requirements-test.txt](requirements-test.txt): Testing dependencies
- [requirements-complete.txt](requirements-complete.txt): Complete dependency list

### Integration Points
- [tasks/celery_app.py](tasks/celery_app.py): Background task processing integration
- [cache/redis_client.py](cache/redis_client.py): Redis caching system
- [api/auth.py](api/auth.py): Authentication API endpoints
- [routes/webhooks.py](routes/webhooks.py): Webhook integration for workflow automation

### Component Relationships

```mermaid
graph TD
    A[app.py] --> B[config.py]
    A --> C[models.py]
    A --> D[session_manager.py]
    A --> E[middleware.py]
    A --> F[database/]
    A --> G[cache/]
    A --> H[tasks/]
    B --> I[config/]
    C --> J[database/]
    D --> K[cache/]
    E --> L[security/]
    F --> M[database/migrations.py]
    G --> N[tasks/celery_app.py]
    A --> O[routes/]
    O --> P[routes/main.py]
    O --> Q[routes/dashboard.py]
    O --> R[routes/approval.py]
    O --> S[routes/status.py]
    A --> T[api/]
    T --> U[api/auth.py]
    T --> V[api/database.py]
```

## 4. Key Features

### Functionality Overview

The SAT Report Generator provides a comprehensive suite of features for report management:

- **User Management**: Role-based access control with Admin, Engineer, Automation Manager, and PM roles
- **Report Creation**: Form-based SAT report generation with template integration
- **Multi-Stage Approval**: Configurable approval workflow with digital signatures
- **Document Generation**: Automated DOCX and PDF report generation
- **Notification System**: Email and in-app notifications for status updates
- **Audit Trail**: Comprehensive logging of user actions and report modifications

### Implementation Highlights

- **Authentication and Authorization**: The system implements a robust authentication system with role-based access control. The [auth.py](auth.py) module handles user login, registration, and session management.

- **Approval Workflow**: The [routes/approval.py](routes/approval.py) module implements a multi-stage approval process where reports progress through Automation Manager and Project Manager approval stages.

- **Document Generation**: The system generates professional reports by populating templates with user data. This is implemented in [routes/main.py](routes/main.py) with integration to the docxtpl library.

- **Database Management**: The [models.py](models.py) file defines a comprehensive data model with relationships between users, reports, approvals, and other entities.

- **Security Features**: The application includes CSRF protection, session management, and security headers to protect against common web vulnerabilities.

### Feature Architecture

```mermaid
stateDiagram-v2
    [*] --> Login
    Login --> Dashboard: Successful authentication
    Dashboard --> CreateReport: Engineer creates report
    CreateReport --> PendingApproval: Submit for approval
    PendingApproval --> AMApproval: Automation Manager review
    AMApproval --> PMApproval: PM review
    PMApproval --> Approved: Final approval
    Approved --> GenerateDocument: Create final report
    GenerateDocument --> NotifyClient: Send to client
    NotifyClient --> Complete
    AMApproval --> Rejected: Rejection
    PMApproval --> Rejected: Rejection
    Rejected --> EditReport: Engineer edits
    EditReport --> PendingApproval
    Dashboard --> ViewReports: View status
    ViewReports --> DownloadReport: Download document
    DownloadReport --> Complete
```

### Data Model

```mermaid
erDiagram
    USER ||--o{ REPORT : creates
    USER ||--o{ NOTIFICATION : receives
    USER ||--o{ APPROVAL : performs
    REPORT ||--|| SAT_REPORT : contains
    REPORT ||--o{ REPORT_VERSION : versions
    REPORT ||--o{ REPORT_COMMENT : comments
    REPORT ||--o{ REPORT_EDIT : edits
    REPORT ||--o{ WEBHOOK : triggers
    REPORT ||--o{ SCHEDULED_REPORT : schedules
    SYSTEM_SETTINGS ||--|| USER : configures
    REPORT_VERSION ||--|| DOCUMENT_TEMPLATE : uses
```

The SAT Report Generator demonstrates a well-structured Flask application with clear separation of concerns, comprehensive feature set, and attention to security and performance considerations. The modular design allows for easy maintenance and future enhancements.
</blog>
